title: get_specific_mutations not working for X or Y chrom
body: only accepting integer chromosome names right now

title: how to deal with vcf records with multiple *ALT*s?
body:
right now we're just picking the longest one...which may not be the smartest choice. essentially, what if you get a SNP and indel at the exact same loci?
          - (rn our code would just pick up the indel)

title: mapping ambiguity between vcf and gtf
body:
some vcf mutations correspond to multiple records in the gtf file; ie. stop codon in one gene could be an exon in another. how to assign these ambiguous vcf hits?

- a relevant question is how often does this happen? if its 0.01% of cases, we can afford to just throw out these ambiguous vcf records

title: are we dealing with deletions properly?
body: im pretty confident were getting insertions, but what about deletions?

title: fathmm filter excludes a bunch of indels
body:
- im pretty sure fathmm is a per-amino acid score, so i dont think it can properly handle indels
- keep this in mind when searching for things like EGFR del19

title: in get_specific_mutations.py it probably makes sense to first subset the cosmic db by gene name
body: - runs wicked fast when i test this on a just-EGFR dataframe

title: germline_filter.py requires 'ID' field to match...this probably makes things too strict
when we reconstruct vcfs during the germline filter step, we excluded the 2 last columns
body:
- _FORMAT_ and this wierd _20_ field dont make the cut...
- probably want to sub out my janky vcf parsing/writing functions for something more official
- ie. pyVCF or VCFpy

title: during vcf reconstruction (germline filter) step, we're literally appending the same vcf header to all our files
body:
- related to #15 
- this is not ideal, we need _INFO_ field to do any sort of coverage analysis

title: how does utils.get_best_overlap deal with genome positions that have multiple hits
body:
- this seems to be most of them...cosmic database has TONS of repeated shit
- specifically the problem is with SNP calling in get_aa_mutations:
       - i want to be able to match CDSs against entries in the cosmic db in order to determine the AA substitution, but what happens if there are multiple cosmic entries, with multiple CDSs
       - `utils.get_best_overlap` is probably just returning the first matching entry, so the CDSs do not necessarily match

title: not picking up intronic variants
body:
in `mutations_table.py`, if a vcf record reports a hit to an intronic region (we think), it will NOT be included in the final table
- this is because while the COSMIC db includes hits to intron, the gtf does not contain entries for intron bounds, so the COSMIC hit wont match anything in the gtf
- solution is probably just not matching back to the gtf when doing the COSMIC filter; ie. just grab the gene name from the COSMIC database line, and dont do the gene matching back to the gtf
- only really need the gtf for the un-filtered case

title: need to integrate coverage module
body:
_a la:_ https://github.com/czbiohub/SNP_calling_pipeline/blob/master/coverage/coverage_search_from_vcf_parallel.py

lets make a new branch for this, and clean it up

title: vcf and cosmic appear to disagree about the strandedness for certain genes?
body:
- originally noticed for BRAF; base positions seem to be reverse complements of each other, as if the reading direction were reversed
- have only seen this in BRAF so far
- not sure how this could be, given both VCF and COSMIC rely on the same reference genome

title: add dbSNP filter, probably in germline_filter.py module
body: fuck

title: perhaps give non-tumor cells better names for germline filtering
body: Right now, my revision of germline filter differentiates tumor from non-tumor bulk-seq VCFs based on the non-tumor cells having three parts (`X_Y_Z.vcf`). It would probably be better to have a more explicit method for differentiating between the bulk-seq VCFs.

title: refactor check_coverage module to work on gene-level, rather than with a user-defined set of ROIs
improve germline filtering: handle multiple ALTs better
body: I was just thinking—right now, the germline filter will only match two records if the `CHROM`, `POS`, `REF`, and `ALT` are all the same. But, since VCFs will encode all mutations that happen at a particular `POS` as multiple `ALT`s, we could instead just check if **one** (not all) of the `ALT`s match, and then remove that `ALT` specifically.

title: vcf '20' field is sometimes malformed
body:
- seeing `0/0:46:46` instead of `1/1:0,2:2:6:84,6,0`
- relevant when trying to extract AD, in `check_coverage_whole_gene` module
- not sure what this edge case means...
- ignoring it for now, with try/except block

title: GenomePosition.from_str shouldn't assume 1-index
body: I've found that BEDtools seems to convert 1-based genome position strings into 0-based ones. Perhaps GenomePosition.from_str should offer an argument allowing one to indicate if the string is 0-based or 1-based.

title: need to integrate gvcf search into coverage module
body:
- if a cell/sample doesnt have a variant, is it because its wildtype, or because it doesnt have coverage
- right now i think this is happening in the summary table module...not ideal

title: look into potential changes in mutation_counts functionality due to GenomePosition.from_vcf_record change
Supporting different types of annotation GTFs
body:
find_aa_mutations soft-requires gencode’s gtf annotation, which for whatever reason has 5 comment lines at the top which pandas doesn’t like
might be good to document somewhere that those have to be removed from the file or add handling so that comment lines are cut off
right now there’s a disparity; mutation_counts’ annotation read_csv call is normal (hg38.gtf), while find_aa_mutations’ has to use `skiprows=5` (gencode .gtf)

title: find-aa-mutations not working, post-merge with Rohan's branch
body: exiting gracefully, but not actually finding variants. I tested on remade artificial vcfs as well as real vcfs, same behavior seen for both. returns empty matrix with only the cell names. merged with `rvanheusen/aa-mutations`. have also checked out raw versions of `rvanheusen/aa-mutations` and `rvanheusen/mutation-counts-cleanup`, and same behavior is observed

title: multiprocessing race condition
body:
was getting a biopython.seq error when running through some new vcf files:

`TranslationError: Codon '>' is invalid`

but seems to have resolved its self somehow

title: output json instead of csv
body:
json might be better suited here because its a better way to represent hierarchical data, such as 
             `cell -> gene -> amino acid mutation` relationships

also nice for very sparse matricies like ours

title: clarification on AD field of vcf files
body:
want to make sure `find_aa_mutations --report_coverage` is pulling out the right thing. 
vcf documentation is not very clear on what information the **AD** field actually contains

title: germline-filter run instructions
body:
Hi,
 
I am trying to run the germline-filter tool but am unclear as to what the contents should be for the metadata csv file.

The message from the tools help page is somewhat vague on the requirements for each argument:

```
Usage: cerebra germline-filter [OPTIONS]

  filter out common SNPs/indels between germline samples and samples of
  interest

Options:
  --processes INTEGER
  --germline TEXT      [required]
  --cells TEXT         [required]
  --metadata TEXT      [required]
  --outdir TEXT        [required]
  -h, --help           Show this message and exit.
```

Please could the run instructions be updated to describe how to run the germline-filter tool with all the required files.

An example dataset would also be useful to demonstrate the required contents of the metadata csv.

Also then just to clarify I am assuming the germline and cells should be the VCF files for each? 

Best wishes,
Roshan

title: JOSS guidelines
body:
something to keep in mind

write up [JOSS](https://joss.theoj.org/) submission in the form of a markdown document (.md)
a nice template to follow comes from @pranathivemuri:  https://github.com/czbiohub/bam2fasta/blob/master/paper/paper.md

JOSS submissions are meant to be very lightweight descriptions of the software, how it works, and testing procedures

the benchmarking figures I have are probably better suited for something like [BMC App Notes](https://biologydirect.biomedcentral.com/submission-guidelines/preparing-your-manuscript/application-notes)

title: make germline-filter module more robust

right now it only works if you have a metadata file with a very specific format

> cell_id,patient_id
sample1,gl_sample1
sample2,gl_sample1
sample3,gl_sample2
sample4,gl_sample2
sample5,gl_sample2

would be nice if we could loosen up this requirement a bit. for example, what if you had germline vcfs for some experimental samples but not all?

can we add a prebuilt index for the human genome .gtf / .fa that would load much faster? 

hg38.fa -> 3 Gb
hg38.gtf -> 144 Mb

title: consider changing mutations -> variants in module names
body: mutations implies functional or perhaps known consequence

title: Versioning question
body:
This repo has only a single release, 1.0.0. However, setup.py sets the version as 1.0.9 and the PyPI version is 1.1.0. `__init__.py` sets the version as 0.1.0.

Additionally, the seemingly-neglected HISTORY.md has only a single entry for 0.1.0 (despite this tag not existing in the repo).

This is important to reconcile as part of https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432

title: Requirements and CI
body:
It looks like conda_requirements.txt is a subset of requirements.txt and conda_requirements.txt is only used by the CI testing.

Why is this file included and why does the CI testing use conda at all? As a user who is looking to install the software, this is quite confusing.

requirements.txt also includes test-only requirements (coverage, flake8, etc.). These should be excluded from the requirements file and standard installation.

https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432

title: Python 3.8 support
body:
The software is not tested against Python 3.8, despite this being the current major release.

I suggest the authors add '3.8' '3.8-dev' and '3.9-dev' to the CI testing, with allowed failures for the dev versions. It also wouldn't hurt to test against (and allow failures for) 'pypy3'. Here is a simple example of this from one of my own projects: https://github.com/CountESS-Project/fqfa/blob/master/.travis.yml

Once 3.8 support is established, it should also be added to the setup.py classifiers section.

https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432

title: Universal wheel
body:
Currently the project has a setup.cfg file that specifies a universal wheel. Based on [the definition in the Python Packaging User Guide](https://packaging.python.org/guides/distributing-packages-using-setuptools/#universal-wheels) this is doesn't seem necessary or correct, since the project does not support Python 2 (nor should it at this point).

https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432

title: Review comments on CONTRIBUTING.md
body:
The CONTRIBUTING.md document includes most of the required material, but there are a few issues.

The links in the document lead to the site home pages rather than the specified pages due to misplaced `>`. The document would benefit from including additional links, such as a link to the relevant GitHub documentation in the first "Get Started!" list item.

This document has very different installation instructions to the README. They should be harmonized, and it will probably be simpler to maintain if CONTRIBUTING refers the user to the README, with notes about changes required to create a dev environment. It's quite confusing to have one document require conda and another require virtualenvwrapper. Ideally both should just use standard library venv.

This document specifies tox but the main project seems to use pytest. The Tips section uses unittest. The project should pick one testing framework and stick to it throughout.

https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432

title: Installation process
body:
Currently the cerebra installation process requires some system packages to be installed. These are all relatively standard requirements that many users will already have. It's good to see that users have the option of running this in Docker. Providing a [Nix expression](https://nixos.org/nix/manual/) is another option.

However, the documentation should be improved with an explanation of why these system packages are needed. They seem to be requirements for cerebra's dependencies rather than the package itself. This transparency is especially important if the dependencies-of-dependencies change in the future.

There are no installation instructions for Windows users, although there are is a large population of bioinformatics specialists who use Windows as their primary environment and might benefit from this software. I'm guessing this is because the package won't install on Windows due to the pysam dependency, but it should be explicitly stated.

The installation instructions for the package itself are not ideal. The primary method of installation (especially for research software with pinned requirements) should be a virtual environment. The primary installation method suggested is a system-level installation.

There are instructions for installing in a virtual environment via conda, but there is no reason I could see to require conda rather than using [standard library's venv](https://docs.python.org/3/library/venv.html). The virtual environment instructions also install the package in editable mode, which is ideal for development but not what most users would be expecting.

The installation section could be split into a "for users" section and a "for developers" section, where the latter describes an editable installation with test requirements and instructions for running unit tests locally.

https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432

title: JoSS Review: Clarify README.md
body:
With regard to the ongoing review for your [JoSS submission](https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432), I would like to suggest stating some sort of use cases and/or warnings in your `README.md`. In particular, one of the largest drawbacks is the case of large VCF files. You even state as much in your [code](https://github.com/czbiohub/cerebra/blob/a6e4463fc6cff5b02583c8020cff09a288cbf598/cerebra/VCF.py#L61-L68):

>```python
> def dataframe(filename, large=True):
>     """ [...]
>     Note: Using large=False with large VCF files. It will be painfully slow.
>     [...]
>     """
> ```

This same cannot be said about your instructions/quickstart.

VCFs can be excruciatingly large sometimes (looking at you 1KG/ENCODE). Many times, researchers want/need to summarize from this starting point. Therefore, suggesting something like _filtering_ the VCF based on region/contig _prior_ to running `cerebra` would be thoughtful suggestion to gung-ho users to preempt potentially long-running jobs.

title: JoSS Review: Quality of writing
body: With regard to the "Quality of writing" section for the ongoing review for your JoSS submission (https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432), these are my (very minor/nitpicky) remarks: * "wrangling" is somewhat parlance and may be a difficult word to discern context from for international audiences * I may be wrong here, but surnames should be written for both in-text and bibliographic citation. For groups of 6 or more, it is acceptable to use "_et al_" after the first author. This simplifies the citation so as to not break up the thought of the sentence any more than it already has. * You are already use LaTex to write the paper, so it may be simpler to write 10^8 as instead * (Question) What happens if a `*.fai` is already provided prior to `find-peptide-variants`? Will it construct a new one? * It might be helpful to state in the caption of **Figure 3** that the first 10+ minutes appear to be the construction of the `genome interval tree` and can be considered overhead for the process, which runs approximately linearly thereafter (Ha! Just saw that you state the same thing just below)

title: JoSS Review: Installation
body:
With regard to the ongoing review for your [JoSS submission](https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432) here are my notes/questions:
1. Why suggest users to install via `pip` in editable (`-e`) mode?
2. For your `pip` installations you could write the command as: `pip install [--user] .` to free up any global install concerns
3. You should preface the OS dependencies _prior_ to the package installation process. This might prevent users from getting towards the end of the install process and throwing up their hands in defeat.

Below are my commands and history from following through the process.

title: JoSS Review: Functionality
body:
With regard to the ongoing review for your [JoSS submission](https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432), here are my notes/questions about the functionality of the package:

1. The hyperlink to [USAGE.md(https://github.com/czbiohub/cerebra/blob/master/docs/USAGE.md) within your [README.md](https://github.com/czbiohub/cerebra/blob/master/README.md) is not pointing to the correct place.
2. This might clear up my 3rd question: What does the `report_coverage` argument for `find-peptide-variants` do and why does it take an integer? If the argument is expecting a boolean, you can tell it to do so as such. If it has a range of options, those should be listed in the `-h` prompt.
3. If I used `1` for `report_coverage`, I got screen full of output that looked like `<class 'hgvs.edit.AASub'> <class 'hgvs.edit.AARefAlt'>`. This looks like somewhere in the code there is a `print()` on an object that does not have a representative `__repr__` or `__str__` methods. Therefore, to anyone that is not knee-deep in the code as a developer may be, this output means nothing to them. Consider defining those methods or making the output more meaningful.
4. What kind of file format is the output of `find-peptide-variants`? If it is a JSON (which I think you describe in the readme [section](https://github.com/czbiohub/cerebra#what-makes-cerebra-different-from-traditional-vcf-parsers)), maybe adding the `.json` suffix to the file path that the user supplies would be helpful. However, my `outfile` produced below does not seem to follow traditional JSON format (I see no brackets).

Below is my command history as detailed in your [README.md](https://github.com/czbiohub/cerebra/blob/master/README.md):

```bash
$ cerebra -h
Usage: cerebra  <command>

  a tool for fast and accurate summarizing of variant calling format (VCF)
  files

Options:
  -h, --help  Show this message and exit.

Commands:
  count-variants         count total number of variants in each sample, and...
  find-peptide-variants  report peptide-level SNPs and indels in each...
  germline-filter        filter out common SNPs/indels between...
$ cerebra germline-filter -h
Usage: cerebra germline-filter [OPTIONS]

  filter out common SNPs/indels between control/germline samples and samples
  of interest

Options:
  --processes INTEGER
  --control_path TEXT       [required]
  --experimental_path TEXT  [required]
  --metadata TEXT           [required]
  --outdir TEXT             [required]
  -h, --help                Show this message and exit.
$ cerebra count-variants -h
Usage: cerebra count-variants [OPTIONS] FILES...

  count total number of variants in each sample, and report on a per-gene
  basis

Options:
  --processes INTEGER
  --cosmicdb TEXT      [required]
  --refgenome TEXT     [required]
  --outfile TEXT       [required]
  -h, --help           Show this message and exit.
$ cerebra find-peptide-variants -h
Usage: cerebra find-peptide-variants [OPTIONS] INPUT_FILES...

  report peptide-level SNPs and indels in each sample, and associated
  coverage

Options:
  --processes INTEGER        number of processes to use for computation
  --cosmicdb TEXT            optional path to cosmic db file (.tsv)
  --annotation TEXT          path to genome annotation (.gtf)  [required]
  --genomefa TEXT            path to full genome sequences (.fasta)
                             [required]

  --report_coverage INTEGER  do you want to report coverage information?
                             [required]

  --output_path TEXT         path to output file  [required]
  -h, --help                 Show this message and exit.
$ cerebra germline-filter --processes 2 --control_path ./germline/ --experimental_path ./experimental/ --metadata meta.csv --outdir ./gl_out/
Running germline filter...
100%|█████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████| 2/2 [00:00<00:00, 18.90it/s]
Done!
$ cat A1.vcf
##fileformat=VCFv4.2
#CHROM  POS ID  REF ALT QUAL    FILTER  INFO
chr1    1   .   A   T,AT    0   .   .
chr1    5   .   C   T,G 0   .   .
chr1    18  .   GG  TAC,G,GC    0   .   .
$ cerebra find-peptide-variants ./vcf/* --processes 2 --cosmicdb cosmic_min.tsv --annotation gencode_min.gtf --genomefa GRCh38_limited_chr7.fa --report_coverage 1 --output_path ./outfile
Beginning setup (this may take several minutes!)
Loading COSMIC database...
Loading genome annotation...
Loading genome sequences...
Building genome trees...
Setup complete.
Finding mutations...
  0%|                                                                                                                                                                                         | 0/5 [00:00<?, ?it/s]<class 'hgvs.edit.AASub'> <class 'hgvs.edit.AARefAlt'>
```

title: JoSS Review: Automated Tests
body:
With regard to the ongoing review for your [JoSS submission](https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432), here are my notes about the automated testing of the package:

Coverage appears to be fine. Tests can be somewhat slow, but that is understandable. I have nothing further to add here.

title: JoSS Review: Community Guidelines
body:
With regard to the ongoing review for your [JoSS submission](https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/issues/2432), here is a thought regarding your Community Guidelines requirement.

I see you have a [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/czbiohub/cerebra/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING.md), but it also may go a long way to create some Issue/bug/feature templates. You can find the process for setting them up here: https://docs.github.com/en/github/building-a-strong-community/configuring-issue-templates-for-your-repository

title: count-variants not runnable without specifying cosmicdb
body:
`count-variants` module cannot be run without specifying a path to a cosmic database file

this is a relatively easy fix
